subject: Physics

figures.description: Velocity–time graph with labeled points M, N, S, P, Q. Segments MN rises, NS is horizontal, SP rises, PQ falls to the time axis. Used in Question 6.
Load (N) versus extension graph with labeled points O, Q, R, S, T, showing elastic and plastic regions. Used in Question 17.
Diagram of stationary wave in a closed tube with wavelength 40 cm and resonating air column length L marked. Used in Question 28.
Capacitor circuit diagram with several capacitors labeled 2µF and 3µF arranged in a network. Used in Question 35.
Transformer diagram with primary (Input) and secondary (Output) windings on a core. Used in Questions 42 and 43.
Set of four I–V plots labeled A, B, C, D. Used in Question 50.

questions.question: Which question paper type of physics is given to you
questions.explanation: The header shows "PAPER TYPE: F".

questions.question: What is the least possible error encountered when taking measurement with a meter rule?
questions.explanation: A meter rule typically has 1 mm smallest division. The least possible reading error is about half the smallest division: \(\pm 0.5\,\text{mm}\).

questions.question: A quantity which requires magnitude and direction to be specified is
questions.explanation: Displacement is a vector quantity (magnitude + direction).

questions.question:
I. Electrical potential
II. Torque
III. Kinetic Energy
IV. Momentum.
Which of the quantities listed are vectors?
questions.explanation: Torque and momentum are vectors. Electrical potential and kinetic energy are scalars.

questions.question: Which type of motion do the wheels of a moving car undergo?
questions.explanation: A rolling wheel rotates about its axle while the car moves forward (translation).

questions.question: From the diagram below, the region of zero acceleration is
questions.explanation: Acceleration is the slope of a velocity–time graph. Zero acceleration corresponds to a horizontal segment; NS is horizontal.

questions.question: A car accelerates uniformly from rest at 3 m s\(^{-2}\); its velocity after traveling a distance of 24 m is
Calculate the escape velocity of a satellite launched from the earth's surface if the radius of the earth is \(6.4\times 10^6\,m\)
questions.explanation: Escape velocity \(v_e=\sqrt{2gR}\). Using \(g\approx 10\,\text{m s}^{-2}\), \(R=6.4\times 10^6\,m\): \(v_e=\sqrt{2\times 10\times 6.4\times 10^6}=\sqrt{1.28\times 10^8}\approx 1.13\times 10^4\,\text{m s}^{-1}=11.3\,\text{km s}^{-1}\).

questions.question: An object of weight 80 kg on earth is taken to a planet where acceleration due to gravity is one-third of its value on earth. The weight of the object on the planet is
questions.explanation: Weight should scale with \(g\): \(W' = \frac{1}{3}W\). However the question states “weight 80 kg” (kg is mass unit), and the answer options are in N but unusually small. If the intended weight was 80 N, then \(W'\approx 26.7\,N\) ≈ 27 N (option C). If intended mass was 80 kg, weight would be hundreds of newtons. Due to this unit inconsistency, the correct option cannot be determined with certainty from the image.

questions.question: One of the conditions necessary for an object to be in equilibrium when acted upon by a number of parallel forces is that the vector sum of the forces is
questions.explanation: For translational equilibrium, the resultant (vector sum) of forces must be zero.

questions.question: What happens when three coplanar non-parallel forces are in equilibrium?

options.text: Their lines of action are parallel.
They are represented in magnitude only
They are represented in direction only
Their lines of action meet at a point

questions.explanation: For three coplanar non-parallel forces to be in equilibrium, their lines of action must be concurrent (meet at one point).

questions.question: An object of mass 20 kg is released from a height of 10 m above the ground level. The kinetic energy of the object just before it hits the ground is
questions.explanation: Ignoring air resistance, loss of PE becomes KE: \(KE=mgh=20\times 10\times 10=2000\,J\).

questions.question: The energy in the nucleus of atoms produce heat which can be used to generate
questions.explanation: Nuclear energy produces heat that drives turbines to generate electrical energy.

questions.question: A machine whose efficiency is 75% is used to lift a load of 1000 N. Calculate the effort put in to the machine if it has a velocity ratio of 4.
questions.explanation: Efficiency \(\eta=\frac{MA}{VR}\). So \(MA=\eta\,VR=0.75\times 4=3\). Since \(MA=\frac{L}{E}\), effort \(E=\frac{L}{MA}=\frac{1000}{3}=333.33\,N\).

questions.question: A wheel and an axle is used to raise a load whose weight is 800 N when an effort of 250 N is applied. If the radii of the wheel and axle are 800 mm and 200 mm respectively, the efficiency of the machine is
questions.explanation: Mechanical advantage \(MA=\frac{800}{250}=3.2\). Velocity ratio \(VR=\frac{800}{200}=4\). Efficiency \(\eta=\frac{MA}{VR}\times 100=\frac{3.2}{4}\times 100=80\%\).

questions.question: A force of 500 N is applied to a steel wire of cross-sectional area 0.2 m\(^2\), the tensile stress is
From the diagram above, the point that represent the elastic limit is
questions.explanation: Elastic limit is the point beyond which deformation is no longer fully elastic (end of Hooke’s law/elastic region). On the typical curve shown, this corresponds to point R.

questions.question: The small droplet of water that forms on the grass in early hours of the morning is
questions.explanation: Dew forms by condensation of water vapour on cool grass surfaces.

questions.question: What is the equivalent of 20 K in Celsius scale?
A glass bottle of initial volume \(2\times 10^4\,\text{cm}^3\) is heated from 20°C to 50°C. If the linear expansively of the glass is \(9\times 10^{-6}\,K^{-1}\), the volume of the bottle at 50°C is
questions.explanation: Volume expansivity \(\beta\approx 3\alpha=3(9\times 10^{-6})=2.7\times 10^{-5}\,K^{-1}\). \(\Delta T=30\,K\). \(\Delta V=\beta V\Delta T = (2.7\times 10^{-5})(2\times 10^4)(30)=16.2\,\text{cm}^3\). New volume \(=20000+16.2=20016.2\,\text{cm}^3\).

questions.question: The equation \(P^aV^bT^c = \text{constant}\) reduces to Charles Law if
questions.explanation: Charles’ law: \(\frac{V}{T}=\text{constant}\) at constant pressure. This corresponds to \(P^0V^1T^{-1}=\text{constant}\), i.e., a=0, b=1, c=-1.

questions.question: The quantity of heat needed to raise the temperature of a body by 1 K is the body's
questions.explanation: Heat capacity is the heat required to raise the temperature of the whole body by 1 K.

questions.question: The melting point of a substance is equivalent to its
questions.explanation: For a pure substance, melting point equals freezing (solidification) point.

questions.question: The temperature at which the water vapor present in the air is just sufficient to saturate air is
questions.explanation: Dew point is the temperature at which air becomes saturated with water vapour.

questions.question: Heat transfer by convection in a liquid is due to the

options.text: latent heat of vaporization of the liquid
increased vibration of the molecules of the liquid about their mean position
variation of density of the liquid
expansion of the liquid as it is heated

questions.explanation: Convection currents arise because heating changes density; less dense (warmer) fluid rises and denser (cooler) fluid sinks.

questions.question: The distance between two successive crests of a wave is 15 cm and the velocity 300 m s^-1. Calculate the frequency.
questions.explanation: Wavelength \(\lambda=15\,cm=0.15\,m\). Frequency \(f=\frac{v}{\lambda}=\frac{300}{0.15}=2000\,Hz=2.0\times 10^3\,Hz\).

questions.question: A boy receives the echo of his clap reflected by a nearby hill 0.8 s later. How far is he from the hill?
questions.explanation: Echo time is for to-and-fro travel. Using \(v\approx 330\,m s^{-1}\): distance \(d=\frac{vt}{2}=\frac{330\times 0.8}{2}=132\,m\). Closest option is C (136 m), not D. (Options suggest a different speed; if \(v=660\,m s^{-1}\) then 264 m. With standard sound speed, C is the closest.)

questions.question: The diagram above show a stationary wave of wavelength 40 cm in a closed tube. The length l is the resonating air column is
questions.explanation: The resonating length depends on whether the pattern corresponds to the fundamental (\(L=\lambda/4\)) or a higher odd harmonic (\(L=3\lambda/4\), etc.). The provided image does not show the node/antinode labeling clearly enough to identify which mode is drawn, so L cannot be determined reliably.

questions.question: An object is placed 10 m from a pinhole camera of length 25 cm. Calculate the linear magnification.
The focal length of a concave mirror is 2.0 cm. If an object is placed 8.0 cm from it, the image is at
questions.explanation: Use mirror formula \(\frac{1}{f}=\frac{1}{u}+\frac{1}{v}\). With \(f=2\,cm\), \(u=8\,cm\): \(\frac{1}{v}=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{8}=\frac{3}{8}\Rightarrow v=\frac{8}{3}=2.67\,cm\). Options are in meters, so there is a unit mismatch; the correct image distance is 2.67 cm.

questions.question: In a compound microscope, the objective and the eye piece focal lengths are
questions.explanation: A compound microscope uses a short focal length objective and a short focal length eyepiece to achieve large magnification; thus “short” best describes them.

questions.question: When a telescope is in normal use, the final image is at
questions.explanation: In normal adjustment, an astronomical telescope forms the final image at infinity for relaxed viewing.

questions.question: When a negatively charged rod is brought near the cap of a charged gold leaf electroscope which has positive charges, the leaf
questions.explanation: A negative rod induces electrons to move toward the cap, reducing positive charge on the leaf and decreasing divergence (collapse).

questions.question: What charge is stored in a 0.1 F capacitor when a 10 V supply is connected across it?
questions.explanation: Charge \(Q=CV=0.1\times 10=1\,C\).

questions.question: Calculate the effective capacitance of the circuit above
questions.explanation: The diagram is too low-resolution to trace the exact series/parallel connections confidently, so the effective capacitance cannot be computed reliably from the provided image.

questions.question: The maximum power transfer occurs in a cell when the external resistance is

options.text: Twice the internal resistance of the cell
The same as the internal resistance of the cell
Greater than the internal resistance of the cell
Less than the internal resistance of the cell

questions.explanation: Maximum power transfer theorem: maximum power is delivered when \(R_{external}=r_{internal}\).

questions.question: If a metal wire 4 m long and crosssectional area 0.8 mm2 has a resistance of 60 Ω, find the resistivity of the wire
questions.explanation: Resistivity \(\rho=\frac{RA}{L}\). Area \(A=0.8\,\text{mm}^2=0.8\times 10^{-6}\,m^2\). \(\rho=\frac{60\times 0.8\times 10^{-6}}{4}=12\times 10^{-6}=1.2\times 10^{-5}\,\Omega m\). None matches exactly; closest is B (3.0×10^-5) or D (3.2×10^-6) but neither equals 1.2×10^-5. This indicates an inconsistency between the given values and options.

questions.question: A circuit has a resistance of 200 Ω. The resistance of the circuit can be reduced to 120 Ω when

options.text: A 300 Ω resistor is connected to it in parallel
An 80 Ω resistor is connected to it in series
A 150 Ω resistor is connected to it in parallel
A 240 Ω resistor is connected to it in series

questions.explanation: Parallel reduces resistance: \(R_{eq}=\frac{200R}{200+R}=120\). Solve: \(120(200+R)=200R\Rightarrow 24000+120R=200R\Rightarrow 24000=80R\Rightarrow R=300\,\Omega\).

questions.question: PHCN measures its electrical energy in
questions.explanation: Electric energy consumption for billing is measured in kilowatt-hour (kWh).

questions.question: What is the best method of demagnetizing a steel bar magnet?
questions.explanation: Best method is using an alternating current in a solenoid and gradually reducing the current (AC demagnetization).

questions.question: The magnitude of the angle of dip at the equator is
questions.explanation: At the magnetic equator, Earth’s field is horizontal, so dip angle is 0°.

questions.question: The diagram above is that of
questions.explanation: The diagram shows separate input and output windings, but the relative number of turns on each side is not clearly readable from the image, so it cannot be classified confidently as step-up or step-down. It is not an auto-transformer (windings appear separate), but between step-up and step-down the required turn ratio is unclear.

questions.question: The electromotive force in the secondary winding is
questions.explanation: A transformer operates with alternating current; the induced emf in the secondary is alternating (time-varying).

questions.question: What type of reaction is represented by the equation \(^{2}_{1}X + ^{2}_{1}X \rightarrow ^{3}_{2}X + ^{1}_{0}n + \text{energy}\)?
questions.explanation: Two light nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus with energy released: nuclear fusion.

questions.question: When an atom undergoes a beta decay, the atomic number of the nucleus
questions.explanation: In \(\beta^-\) decay, a neutron turns into a proton, so atomic number increases by 1.

questions.question: Calculate the mass of the copper deposited during electrolysis when a current of 4 A passes through a copper salt for 2 hours. [ece of Copper \(z=3.3\times 10^{-7}\,\text{kg C}^{-1}\)]
questions.explanation: Charge \(Q=It=4\times (2\times 3600)=28800\,C\). Mass \(m=zQ=(3.3\times 10^{-7})(28800)=9.504\times 10^{-3}\,kg\). This matches option C, not D.

questions.question: Which gas produces a pink coloured light in a discharge tube?
questions.explanation: Neon gives a characteristic reddish/pink glow in discharge tubes (neon lamps).

questions.question: When \(^{210}_{82}\text{Pb}\) decays to \(^{206}_{80}\text{Pb}\), it emits

options.text: two alpha and two beta particles
one alpha and one beta particle

questions.explanation: Mass number drops 210→206 (−4) and atomic number drops 82→80 (−2), which corresponds to alpha emission.

questions.question: In a common emitter configuration, the output voltage is through the
questions.explanation: In a common-emitter amplifier, the output is taken from the collector circuit (collector relative to emitter).

questions.question: Which of the graph below shows the characteristic of an i-v transistor?
questions.explanation: A transistor output characteristic typically rises with voltage and then tends toward saturation (levels off). Among the shown plots, graph D best matches that shape.

missingQuestions: Question 9 has unit inconsistency ("weight 80 kg") which prevents a unique correct option selection.
Question 28 stationary wave mode is not legible enough to identify the correct resonant length.
Question 30 options are in meters while computation gives centimeters (unit mismatch).
Question 35 capacitor network is not legible enough to compute equivalent capacitance.
Question 42 step-up vs step-down cannot be decided because turns ratio is not readable.
